Finding View Differences

With the View Comparison utility, you can use the Find Differences command on the View menu to search for differences within the views. This command finds the first folder or pair of corresponding folders that meet your criteria for the type of item on the selected tab. On the item pane, the application displays the items within these folders that match your search criteria.

Caution: Remember that two folders with the same name may or may not correspond.

When the application searches for differences, several key elements are critical:

  • The search criteria specified in the Find Differences dialog.

  • The tab selected from the item pane. The selected search criteria apply to only one type of item at a time.

  • The specific pane (source or target pane) active at the time you selected search options from the Find Differences dialog. The active pane is underscored with a specific color (by default, dark blue). You must select the pane for the view to which you want to make changes, as this will be the destination for any merge.

    • If the source pane is active, Find Differences locates items in the target that need to be merged to the source. If the target pane is active, Find Differences locates items in the source that need to be merged to the target.   To find all items that need to be merged with the source and all items that need to be merged with the target,  you must search first in one direction, then in the other. Between searches, you must change the active pane, and reset the search options using the Find Differences dialog.

    To locate all items to be merged, regardless of direction, select Item > Display and clear the Use merge tracking for merge resolution option. All items to be merged will then show a two-way arrow icon, which simply indicates that they differ from one another.

  • The folder selected on the active pane. You can start the search with this folder.

  • The folder selected on the pane that is not active. You can limit the search to a branch of the folder hierarchy in the inactive pane by selecting the folder that is the root of that branch.

  • The display setting for the item pane. If this setting is not correct, you will not be able to see the items that match your search criteria.

To find folders containing items that match your search criteria:

  1. Open the view to be used as the source.

  2. Click View > Compare/Merge to select the view that will serve as the target.

  3. Select a folder from the source pane and a folder from the target pane.

  4. Click the source pane or the target pane to make it active.

  5. Select a tab from the lower pane to specify the type of item to which the search criteria will apply.

  6. Select the display setting for your items. Be careful that your choice is appropriate. It is recommended that you select Item > Display > All Items or Item > Display > All Items With Differences so that you can see any items in the item pane that match your search criteria.

  7. (Optional) To limit the search, select a folder from the inactive pane. Do one of the following:

    • If you plan to compare the source view with the target view, select a folder from the target folder hierarchy as the root of the branch to be searched.

    • If you plan to compare the target view with the source view, select a folder from the source folder hierarchy as the root of the branch to be searched.

  8. Specify the pane that will initiate the comparison by making it the active pane. Select the source or the target by clicking the pane or selecting a folder in the pane. The selected folder can also indicate where the search should start.

    9. When the source pane is active, the application compares the source view with the target view, and vice versa. If neither pane is active (the cursor is in the item pane), the application compares the source view with the target view.

  9. Do one of the following:

    • Select Find Differences from the View or context menu.

    • Click the Find Differences button on the toolbar.

    • Press Ctrl + F.

      • The Find Differences dialog opens. The dialog title is Find Differences in Source View or Find Differences in Target View, depending on which pane is currently active.

  10. Select or clear one or more check boxes to specify the differences in which you are interested.

    • Select the Items that need to be merged check box to locate corresponding folders that contain items that are different in each folder and need to be merged.

    • Select the Item only in source view check box to locate corresponding folders in which the source folder has at least one item that is not in the target folder.

    • Select the Item only in target view check box to locate corresponding folders in which the target folder has at least one item that is not in the source folder.

    • Select the No matching folder in source/target view check box to locate a folder in the active view that has no corresponding folder in the inactive view. (This is the only search criteria check box that is unrelated to the tab selected from the item pane.)

  11. Select the Root folder or Selected folder option button to indicate where the search should start in the active pane.

  12. (Optional) Select the Restrict source/target view scope to selected folder branch check box to search only a branch of the folder hierarchy in the inactive pane. The folder selected in the inactive pane is the root of that branch.

  13. Click OK. The application finds the first folder or pair of corresponding folders that meet your criteria for the type of item indicated by your tab selection. From the item pane,the application selects the items within these folders that match your search criteria.

    14. If you are searching only for child folders that have no corresponding folders in the other view, ignore the contents of the item pane. Your search will apply only to the folder hierarchy. If you are using additional search criteria, be careful to distinguish between folders that have no corresponding folders (for which you should ignore the contents of the item pane) and folders that have corresponding folders (for which you should view the contents of the item pane). When no corresponding folder exists, a folder is selected from the active pane, the root folder is selected from the inactive pane, and nothing is selected in the item pane.

  14. (Optional) Do one of the following:

    • Find the next difference by selecting Find Next Difference from the View or context menu, clicking the Find Next Difference button on the toolbar, or pressing F3.

    • Find the previous difference by selecting Find Previous Difference from the View or context menu, clicking the Find Previous Difference button on the toolbar or pressing Shift + F3.

    Important:  Finding the next or previous difference is based on the criteria you previously set for a search, even you have changed the active pane since that time. Changing the tab at the bottom of the window changes the type of item to which the search is applied, but changing the active window does not change the direction of the search.
